When you think about attending, how does that make you feel? Have you had any past experiences with similar situations that come to mind? turns.client_last:
Yeah, I mean, it's just... the thought of being there, surrounded by family, it makes me anxious. I start imagining all the questions they might ask, like about my job or my life, and I just don't want to get into it. It feels like they’re judging me the whole time. I remember how it was at other family gatherings, feeling like I had to put on a front, and it just... it never felt genuine. 

Honestly, I think I just want to avoid the discomfort. I know I should be happy for my cousin, but the idea of being there and feeling out of place, it just makes me want to hide away. I guess I just feel like no one really wants me there anyway, so why put myself through that?

turns.therapist_last: It sounds like you’re really feeling the weight of anxiety about the wedding and the pressure from your family. I can understand your desire to avoid that discomfort, especially given how past experiences have shaped your feelings about family gatherings. The belief that no one wants you there must be really tough to carry, and it seems to connect deeply with those earlier moments of feeling judged or out of place. I’d like to hear more about what genuine connection would look like for you in situations like this. What would make you feel more at ease or accepted?
turns.client_last:
I guess... I don’t really know what genuine connection looks like for me anymore. It feels like everyone is just... pretending, you know? Like we’re all just going through the motions. I mean, what’s the point of being there if I can’t be myself? I used to think that if I just acted like everything was fine, maybe they’d like me better or see me differently. But it just didn’t work out that way.

I think if I felt like I could be honest about who I am, maybe it would change things. But then I remember my mom and how she always made me feel like I was never good enough. So, I don’t know... it’s hard to shake that feeling of being unlovable or unwanted. It’s just easier to avoid the whole situation and not deal with the disappointment. I guess I’m just scared of being judged again or feeling like I don’t belong.

turns.therapist_last: It sounds like you’re grappling with some deep feelings about connection and acceptance, especially in light of your past experiences with your mom and family gatherings. I’d like to ask you to describe what being yourself would look like in a family setting. What do you envision when you think about being genuine around your family? Also, are there specific fears that come up for you about being judged at the wedding? Let’s explore that a bit more.
turns.client_last:
I mean, being myself in a family setting... that’s a tough one to picture. I guess I imagine it would mean not having to pretend or put on a show. Just feeling free to talk about what I really think and feel without worrying about how others will react. But then, I can’t help but think about how my mom would probably still find something to criticize. It’s like that voice in my head just won’t go away, telling me I’m not good enough to be accepted as I am.

As for the fears about being judged at the wedding, I just keep thinking about the questions they might ask, like about my weight or why I haven’t settled down yet. It’s like they're just waiting to point out what’s wrong with me, you know? I can almost hear their whispers, and it makes me feel so small. I feel like no matter what I do, it won’t be enough for them. So, it’s just easier to avoid it altogether and spare myself the pain.

turns.therapist_last: I appreciate you sharing those feelings, Alex. Can you recall a specific moment in the past when you felt judged or unlovable? What was happening at that time, and what thoughts went through your mind? I’d like to help you frame that thought clearly, perhaps something like “I am not good enough.” How does that thought resonate with you in the context of attending the wedding? Let’s also explore how that thought might influence your desire to avoid the event altogether.
turns.client_last:
I guess one moment that stands out to me was at a family gathering a few years ago. Everyone was talking about their lives, their jobs, and I just felt like I was on the outside looking in. I remember my aunt asked me what I was doing with my life, and I just froze. All I could think was that I didn’t have a good answer. I felt this wave of judgment wash over me like... like I was somehow failing everyone. 

It’s like I could hear that voice in my head saying, “See? You’re not good enough. They’re all looking down on you.” That thought just spiraled. I ended up saying something vague to brush it off, but inside, I felt so small and unworthy. It was like I was just a disappointment to everyone, and I couldn’t shake that feeling for days afterward.

Thinking about the wedding, it’s like I’m bracing myself for that same kind of judgment. I can’t help but wonder if they’ll be thinking the same things about me again. And then I think, why even put myself in that position where I’ll feel that way again? It just feels safer to avoid it, you know? It’s easier to stay away than to risk feeling that pain again.

turns.therapist_last: Let’s take a moment to unpack that thought, “I am not good enough.” Can you identify any evidence that supports this belief? At the same time, let’s consider if there’s any evidence that contradicts it. Reflecting on past experiences, can you think of times when you felt accepted or valued, even if they were brief? I’m also curious about how this belief influences your feelings about attending the wedding. Lastly, if a friend came to you expressing a similar belief about themselves, what would you say to them?
turns.client_last:
I mean, it’s tough to look at it that way. I can think of times when I felt accepted, like maybe when I was with friends who didn’t care about my weight or my job status. They liked me for who I was, and I felt like I could be myself. But those moments seem so fleeting compared to the times I felt judged. It feels like the judgment sticks with me way longer than the acceptance does.

As for evidence supporting that belief, I guess I just look at my family and how they act, like when my aunt asked me about my life. That felt like a big reminder of everything I’m not. But if I try to think of evidence against it, I guess I can remember moments where I’ve had good conversations with people, or when someone complimented my work. It’s just hard to hold onto those moments when the negative ones seem to drown them out.

Thinking about going to the wedding, that belief makes me feel like I’m just setting myself up for more disappointment. If I go, I feel like I’ll just end up feeling unworthy again, and it’s exhausting to think about. If a friend came to me feeling like that, I’d probably tell them they’re more than that one moment, that they’re valuable and deserving of love. But when it’s me, it just feels different. I don’t know why it’s so much harder to believe it for myself.

turns.client_last:
I mean, when I think about those moments with friends, like when we’d just hang out and laugh without any judgment, it feels so different from family gatherings. It’s like I can actually see myself for who I am in those moments, not just the labels or judgments others put on me. But, you know, those times are rare. When I think back to my family, it’s hard to separate those feelings of judgment from the love I want to feel. 

Those moments with friends challenge the belief a little, but it’s still hard to shake the feeling that I’m not good enough for my family. It’s almost like their opinions weigh more, and those past experiences just keep echoing in my mind. 

Thinking about going to the wedding, I feel this mix of anxiety and dread. It’s like I can picture myself walking in and just feeling that sense of being an outsider again. The thought of being judged really weighs me down. It’s exhausting to think about having to put up a front again, pretending everything’s fine when inside I’m just... not. 

If I were to talk to myself like I would to a friend, I guess I’d tell myself that it’s okay to feel anxious and that it doesn’t define my worth. I’d probably say I deserve to be there just as much as anyone else, and that it’s okay to be honest about my feelings. But then I wonder if I can really believe that for myself. It’s like there’s this wall I just can’t break through.

I guess the specific thought that comes to mind is definitely “I am not good enough.” That thought just seems to loom over me whenever I think about family events. It’s like I can feel my heart racing and my stomach dropping at the same time. It fills me with dread about attending the wedding because I just know those feelings of judgment are going to come rushing back.

turns.client_last:
It’s hard to pinpoint specific instances that support that belief. I mean, I think back to those family gatherings where I felt like I was being scrutinized. Like that time at my aunt's house, when everyone was talking about their achievements, and I just felt... invisible. I could almost feel the weight of their expectations pressing down on me. It was like I was under a microscope, and every little thing was magnified. 

But then, when I think about those moments with friends, it’s such a contrast. There were times when we’d joke around, share stories, and I felt accepted just for being me. Those moments felt genuine, and it was like all those judgments faded away. But they seem so rare compared to the experiences with my family. It feels like those negative feelings are just so much louder.

Thinking about the wedding, that belief just makes the whole idea feel so daunting. I can already picture walking in and feeling that sense of inadequacy wash over me. It’s like I’m preparing for battle, but I don’t even know if I have the strength to fight. It’s exhausting to even think about putting myself in that situation again, where I might feel judged or out of place.

If a friend came to me feeling like they weren’t good enough, I’d tell them that everyone has their struggles and that they’re worth so much more than their doubts. I’d remind them that they have people who care about them, just like I do for my friends. But when it comes to myself, it’s like I can’t quite extend that same compassion. It’s frustrating, and I just feel stuck. I don’t know how to break free from that cycle.

I mean, when I really think about it, “I am not good enough” feels like this heavy weight that just settles in whenever I think about family events, especially the wedding. turns.therapist_last:
It’s clear that the thought “I am not good enough” carries a lot of weight for you, especially when it comes to family gatherings like the wedding. I want to acknowledge that feeling; it’s understandable given your past experiences. Now, let’s try to find a more balanced thought that acknowledges both your anxiety and those positive moments with friends where you felt accepted. How might you view the wedding as an opportunity for connection, rather than a situation filled with judgment? 

As you think about that, can you identify specific strengths or qualities you possess that would be valuable in a family setting? It might help to remind yourself of these strengths when you start to feel overwhelmed. Lastly, how could you approach the wedding with a mindset that allows for both vulnerability and authenticity, embracing who you are while also being open to connection?
turns.client_last:
I mean, I can see how thinking of the wedding as an opportunity for connection could be a different perspective. But honestly, it feels really hard to shift my mindset like that. The idea of being around family still brings up so much anxiety. I guess I could try to remind myself that not every interaction has to be filled with judgment, but it's tough to shake off that feeling of being under scrutiny.

When I think about my strengths, I suppose I can be a good listener and I’m pretty empathetic. I’ve had friends tell me that I’m supportive when they need someone to talk to. I guess those qualities could help me connect with family members if I let myself be open about my feelings. 

But then there's this fear that if I show my true self, they might still judge me or not understand where I’m coming from. It's like I want to embrace who I am, but I also want to protect myself from that potential hurt. It’s just a balancing act that feels overwhelming right now. 

Maybe if I could approach the wedding thinking that I’m there to support my cousin and maybe even reconnect with family, that could help ease some of the pressure. I just wish I could genuinely believe that I’m worthy of being there, flaws and all. But that fear still looms large and makes it hard to see the positives. I guess I’m just really struggling to bridge that gap between wanting connection and fearing judgment.

full_conversation.content: Hi Alex, it’s great to see you today. What’s been on your mind that brings you here to talk with me?

I guess... I’ve been thinking about my cousin’s wedding. He invited me, and it’s just... I don’t know, it feels overwhelming. I mean, weddings are supposed to be happy, right? But for me, it just feels like a lot of pressure. I can’t help but think about how everyone will be looking at me or asking questions. It’s like... I’m not sure I want to deal with that right now.

It sounds like the wedding is really weighing on you. Can you share more about what specifically feels overwhelming about it? When you think about attending, how does that make you feel? Have you had any past experiences with similar situations that come to mind? I'm also curious about what you hope to gain or avoid by deciding to go or not go to the wedding. It's completely okay to feel conflicted about social events like this.

Yeah, I mean, it's just... the thought of being there, surrounded by family, it makes me anxious. I start imagining all the questions they might ask, like about my job or my life, and I just don't want to get into it. It feels like they’re judging me the whole time. I remember how it was at other family gatherings, feeling like I had to put on a front, and it just... it never felt genuine. 

Honestly, I think I just want to avoid the discomfort. I know I should be happy for my cousin, but the idea of being there and feeling out of place, it just makes me want to hide away. I guess I just feel like no one really wants me there anyway, so why put myself through that?

It sounds like you’re really feeling the weight of anxiety about the wedding and the pressure from your family. I can understand your desire to avoid that discomfort, especially given how past experiences have shaped your feelings about family gatherings. The belief that no one wants you there must be really tough to carry, and it seems to connect deeply with those earlier moments of feeling judged or out of place. I’d like to hear more about what genuine connection would look like for you in situations like this. What would make you feel more at ease or accepted?

I guess... I don’t really know what genuine connection looks like for me anymore. It feels like everyone is just... pretending, you know? Like we’re all just going through the motions. I mean, what’s the point of being there if I can’t be myself? I used to think that if I just acted like everything was fine, maybe they’d like me better or see me differently. But it just didn’t work out that way.

I think if I felt like I could be honest about who I am, maybe it would change things. But then I remember my mom and how she always made me feel like I was never good enough. So, I don’t know... it’s hard to shake that feeling of being unlovable or unwanted. It’s just easier to avoid the whole situation and not deal with the disappointment. I guess I’m just scared of being judged again or feeling like I don’t belong.

It sounds like you’re grappling with some deep feelings about connection and acceptance, especially in light of your past experiences with your mom and family gatherings. I’d like to ask you to describe what being yourself would look like in a family setting. What do you envision when you think about being genuine around your family? Also, are there specific fears that come up for you about being judged at the wedding? Let’s explore that a bit more.

I mean, being myself in a family setting... that’s a tough one to picture. I guess I imagine it would mean not having to pretend or put on a show. Just feeling free to talk about what I really think and feel without worrying about how others will react. But then, I can’t help but think about how my mom would probably still find something to criticize. It’s like that voice in my head just won’t go away, telling me I’m not good enough to be accepted as I am.

As for the fears about being judged at the wedding, I just keep thinking about the questions they might ask, like about my weight or why I haven’t settled down yet. It’s like they're just waiting to point out what’s wrong with me, you know? I can almost hear their whispers, and it makes me feel so small. I feel like no matter what I do, it won’t be enough for them. So, it’s just easier to avoid it altogether and spare myself the pain.

I appreciate you sharing those feelings, Alex. Can you recall a specific moment in the past when you felt judged or unlovable? What was happening at that time, and what thoughts went through your mind? I’d like to help you frame that thought clearly, perhaps something like “I am not good enough.” How does that thought resonate with you in the context of attending the wedding? Let’s also explore how that thought might influence your desire to avoid the event altogether.

I guess one moment that stands out to me was at a family gathering a few years ago. Everyone was talking about their lives, their jobs, and I just felt like I was on the outside looking in. I remember my aunt asked me what I was doing with my life, and I just froze. All I could think was that I didn’t have a good answer. I felt this wave of judgment wash over me like... like I was somehow failing everyone. 

It’s like I could hear that voice in my head saying, “See? You’re not good enough. They’re all looking down on you.” That thought just spiraled. I ended up saying something vague to brush it off, but inside, I felt so small and unworthy. It was like I was just a disappointment to everyone, and I couldn’t shake that feeling for days afterward.

Thinking about the wedding, it’s like I’m bracing myself for that same kind of judgment. I can’t help but wonder if they’ll be thinking the same things about me again. And then I think, why even put myself in that position where I’ll feel that way again? It just feels safer to avoid it, you know? It’s easier to stay away than to risk feeling that pain again.

Let’s take a moment to unpack that thought, “I am not good enough.” Can you identify any evidence that supports this belief? At the same time, let’s consider if there’s any evidence that contradicts it. Reflecting on past experiences, can you think of times when you felt accepted or valued, even if they were brief? I’m also curious about how this belief influences your feelings about attending the wedding. Lastly, if a friend came to you expressing a similar belief about themselves, what would you say to them?

I mean, it’s tough to look at it that way. I can think of times when I felt accepted, like maybe when I was with friends who didn’t care about my weight or my job status. They liked me for who I was, and I felt like I could be myself. But those moments seem so fleeting compared to the times I felt judged. It feels like the judgment sticks with me way longer than the acceptance does.

As for evidence supporting that belief, I guess I just look at my family and how they act, like when my aunt asked me about my life. That felt like a big reminder of everything I’m not. But if I try to think of evidence against it, I guess I can remember moments where I’ve had good conversations with people, or when someone complimented my work. It’s just hard to hold onto those moments when the negative ones seem to drown them out.

Thinking about going to the wedding, that belief makes me feel like I’m just setting myself up for more disappointment. If I go, I feel like I’ll just end up feeling unworthy again, and it’s exhausting to think about. If a friend came to me feeling like that, I’d probably tell them they’re more than that one moment, that they’re valuable and deserving of love. But when it’s me, it just feels different. I don’t know why it’s so much harder to believe it for myself.

Let’s take a closer look at those moments when you felt accepted and valued. Can you think of specific instances that support your belief of not being good enough? Now, let’s also reflect on those positive experiences you mentioned with friends who appreciated you for who you are. How do those moments challenge the belief that you’re not worthy? As we think about attending the wedding, how do these thoughts and feelings influence your emotions about going? Lastly, if you were to approach this situation with the same compassion you’d offer a friend, what might you say to yourself?

I mean, when I think about those moments with friends, like when we’d just hang out and laugh without any judgment, it feels so different from family gatherings. It’s like I can actually see myself for who I am in those moments, not just the labels or judgments others put on me. But, you know, those times are rare. When I think back to my family, it’s hard to separate those feelings of judgment from the love I want to feel. 

Those moments with friends challenge the belief a little, but it’s still hard to shake the feeling that I’m not good enough for my family. It’s almost like their opinions weigh more, and those past experiences just keep echoing in my mind. 

Thinking about going to the wedding, I feel this mix of anxiety and dread. It’s like I can picture myself walking in and just feeling that sense of being an outsider again. The thought of being judged really weighs me down. It’s exhausting to think about having to put up a front again, pretending everything’s fine when inside I’m just... not. 

If I were to talk to myself like I would to a friend, I guess I’d tell myself that it’s okay to feel anxious and that it doesn’t define my worth. I’d probably say I deserve to be there just as much as anyone else, and that it’s okay to be honest about my feelings. But then I wonder if I can really believe that for myself. It’s like there’s this wall I just can’t break through.

I appreciate your willingness to explore these feelings, Alex. Can you identify the specific thought that comes to mind when you feel judged by your family, perhaps something like “I am not good enough”? How does that thought influence your feelings about attending the wedding? I’d also like you to reflect on how this thought has shaped your past experiences at family gatherings. It’s like I can feel my heart racing and my stomach dropping at the same time. It fills me with dread about attending the wedding because I just know those feelings of judgment are going to come rushing back. 

When I think about past experiences with my family, that thought has shaped so much. I remember feeling like I had to keep my head down, avoid eye contact, and just hope I wouldn’t be asked anything too personal. It’s like I’m stuck in this loop where I can’t break free from those feelings of inadequacy. 

If a friend came to me feeling this way, I’d probably remind them that everyone has their struggles and that they’re not defined by those moments of doubt. I’d encourage them to see their value beyond what others might think. But when it’s me, I just can’t seem to apply that same kindness to myself. It feels like I’m in this tight bubble, and the thought of bursting it to face that judgment—it’s just so overwhelming. I don’t know if I have it in me to challenge that belief right now.

It’s hard to pinpoint specific instances that support that belief. I mean, I think back to those family gatherings where I felt like I was being scrutinized. But then, when I think about those moments with friends, it’s such a contrast. There were times when we’d joke around, share stories, and I felt accepted just for being me. Those moments felt genuine, and it was like all those judgments faded away. But they seem so rare compared to the experiences with my family. It feels like those negative feelings are just so much louder.

Thinking about the wedding, that belief just makes the whole idea feel so daunting. I can already picture walking in and feeling that sense of inadequacy wash over me. It’s exhausting to even think about putting myself in that situation again, where I might feel judged or out of place.

If a friend came to me feeling like they weren’t good enough, I’d tell them that everyone has their struggles and that they’re worth so much more than their doubts.
